definition: to make a fool of oneself
variant of 鬧|闹[nao4]
noisy/cacophonous/to make noise/to disturb/to vent (feelings)/to fall ill/to have an attack (of sickness)/to go in (for some activity)/to joke
old variant of 笑[xiao4]
laugh/smile/CL:個|个[ge4]
dialect/language/spoken words/speech/talk/words/conversation/what sb said/CL:種|种[zhong3],席[xi2],句[ju4],口[kou3],番[fan1]
old variant of 話|话[hua4]

sentences.english: You can always rely on him making a fool of himself.
sentences.chinese: 你可以想象他一定会闹笑话。

sentences.english: No more beef fingers, no more drama from now on, I promise.
sentences.chinese: 不再竖中指，不再闹笑话，我保证。

sentences.english: Don't make a fool of yourself anymore.
If you pretend to know what you don't know, you'll only make a fool of yourself.
Such stereotypes often lead to unusual and sometimes amusing situations.
sentences.chinese: 这种成见常常会引发一些怪事，有时还会闹笑话。

definition: to make a fool of oneself
to make a fool of oneself/to make oneself a laughing stock
to lose face
shameful/scandalous/to be humiliated/to make a fool of sb or oneself/to make sb lose face
to leak/to expose (sb's secret)/to spill the beans/to let the cat out of the bag
erhua variant of 露餡|露馅[lou4 xian4]
(coll.) to have sth embarrassing happen
joke/jest/CL:個|个[ge4]/to laugh at/to mock
to laugh one's head off/ridiculous/jaw-dropping
to overreach oneself/to try to be clever and end up with egg on one's face
social gaffe or blunder/faux pas/see 出洋相[chu1 yang2 xiang4]
lit. to put Zhang's hat on Li's head/to attribute sth to the wrong person (idiom)/to confuse one thing with another
to go wrong/to take a wrong turning
to try to draw a tiger but end up with a likeness of a dog (idiom)/to try to do sth overambitious and end up botching it
pinyin: hua4 hu3 bu4 cheng2 fan3 lei4 quan3

definition: to lose face
to confuse (fail to differentiate)
